This is not intended to be a creation evolution debate and I hope folks will refrain from that.
 
 I believe that there are characteristics which are solely attributable to humans. Before I post my thoughts I would like to hear others. I don't wish to influence any answers. 
 
 So what do you all think. By the Way, "nothing" is also a reasonable response, but it will be hard to prove.

I think the difference is that apes act on instinct. They only know to find shelter, find food, and protect the young. Meanwhile, humans choose to act on their own free will. Because the human mind wonders and questions, humans decide for themselves what they want to be, what is right, what is wrong, and the results of their actions. Humans tend to focus on time/causes and results. Meanwhile, apes care only for the present and what their natural instincts tell them to do. 
 
 Other than that, apes are hairy and look awkward.

Man is the only animal that blushes. Or needs to. 
 ~ Mark Twain [Samuel Langhorne Clemens] (1835-1910), U.S. author. Following the Equator, ch. 27, "Pudd'nhead Wilson's New Calendar," (1897). 
 
 :)

As much as we try to ignore it, we are simply higher order animals who act on complex, but still instictive, reasoning. The reasoning aspect got us this far, to guns and cities and civilizations, but our base drivings have not changed, we still want food, shelter, and to make children (as so perfectly said by "Philosopher"). We share all our base motivations with wolfs, elephants, moose, monkeys, etc., but the thing that changes us and makes us "superior" is our ability to create startigized formula on how to acheieved our base goals I.E. food, shelter and making kids. 
 
 We are not sentient, we are not brilliant. We are simply planning apes. It is really comforting to think of ourselves as better then our fellow animals, that we are somehow gifted with sentient thought, but we are not. The majority of what we do with our lives can usally fall into one of three catagories. The need to continue or better the species, the need for self-preservation and the need for command of the social higher-archy (alpha's), or to be a memeber of it, and to be accepted by it (beta's). Try to think of something you do that dosen't fit into one of these three. In case you were wondering, "blushing" falls into the last catagory. 
 
 
 In summary, the big diffrence between us and apes is that we stand on 2 feet all the time, and that we can plan longer-term then any other animal on this planet. (the main reason we are afraid of death)
 
 P.S. Philosopher, all social animals, excluding drone societies, have at least a basic understanding of the whole cause and effect thing. Gorilla's undertand if they anger the silverback, they are going to get beat up. They understand like we do, if I do this act, I will get this response, and they have to make a choice as to if the response they get will be unfavourable or favourable. A.k.a Good or Bad. Also, only drone societies act soully on instinct, most other animals in the world have varying degrees of freewill as to what they do. 
 
 Example-
 Some dogs can live peacefully with cats, and some dogs can't be put within 2 miles of anything remotely looking like a cat. Instincts are universial to a species, until the species mutates or branches off. So how can our two example dogs (both coming from the same mother) have such a varying degree of opinion over the subject of cats if they do not have atleast basic freewill?

As much as we try to ignore it, we are simply higher order animals who act on complex, but still instictive, reasoning. ...
 

 
 
 Throw just a few more genes into the soup, stir the DNA pot a bit, and POOF!
 @( $ /|\ $ )@

 epaphras_faith, as I was just saying, Science has laready defined the exact nature of the difference (i.e. having to do with a specific definition of the word "conscious"). However, the damn definition would take a while to study, before anyone could hope to paraphrase it!
 
 We keep redefining the difference, as the years and studies go on. It's just become too damn difficult for any layman to remember what the damn difference is! LOL!!! BTW....
 
 Someone above mentioned fear of death. That too is not specific to humans.
 Chimps and even lower ranking animals like birds have specific warning signs for specific dangers, and when you see a troop of 40 baboons scamper up a tree so fast that they leave some hair behind, you can pretty much bet that
 they fear death from a snake, or a large predator, and didn't all get hungry for tree bark or leaves, at the same time. So, I think fear of death can be ruled out as being specific to humans.

Animals fear staravtion and deadly animals on instinct, they are programed to fear death because of the instinct of self-preservation. Humans see death as inevitable and that is the longer-term planning reprocussion.

Wow, finally someone came to the philosophy section. I posted this on the creation vs. evolution thread as well just to get a bite.
 
 I will ask a similar question, How is religion instinctual? Are we the culmination of evolution, if not, what is the next level? Is the planet of the apes possible?

PLANET OF THE APES THING=
 Unfortunatly for us, yes. And very likely if we just disappered. 
 
 RELIGION THING=
 As I said humans follow three catgories, self-preservation, the soical thing, and the need to continue or better the species. We see in the very long term, and have high orders of reasoning that allow us to get what we want.
 That is how we got here, but we see death as something outside our long-term ability to plan for, and that just messes with the need for self-preservation. So, because we are creatures that need to have answers (not because god said so, but because creatures that want the answer on how to get that peice of fruit up in that tree to fall down, will do better then the creature that dosen't care), we create eloborate teachings that allow us to incorporate death into our long-term plans, and that takes away from the whole self-preservation fear. No offense to religious guys, but seriously if you think about it, isn't it convinent that god will let us into heaven. Every culture has some version of eternity written into its teachings, weither it be heaven, rebirth or some nature thing it is what we want to believe. 
 
 I admit in my weaker momments I have really wished I did believe in some kind of god, but the fact remains, most of our lives we act on complex instinct. The thing that seperates us now that we have got metaphorically "Situated" as a civilization is the few moments we walk in to transedental territory. That time we figure out the math problem, that time we figure out the riddle, that, more then anything, is the definition of consiousness I go by. Everything else in life, religion, love, hate etc. are just things we use to satisfy our base needs (re-read my first post for clarification) but those seconds, when we finally grasp an idea, when it dosen't change us in any way, but we feel profoundly happy at our own ability to grasp the riddle, math problem, board game etc. is something no other animal feels. They may feel happy at having, going back to the fruit in a tree example, knocked the fruit out of the tree, and are happy now because they get to eat the fruit. Humanity is "sentient" because we enjoy the fact that we knocked the fruit out of the tree more then we enjoy the fruit itself.
 
 Atleast thats what I think defines consiousness I could be wrong, but I know for sure what dosen't and religion is something any animal with enough reasoning and foresight would invent.

 It may not seem linked to the topic but something you said brought it up. I will clarify my link for it to this topic later. But, Why is there death?

From a philisophical stand point death is the motivation for our lives. 
 
 From the sceince stand point, death seems a pretty basic concept. 
 In evolution new mutations are the only way to keep the speices from being wiped out by a virus, new predeator etc., and if the new mutations have to compete for mates and food with the older generation, then the older generation will most likely survive. The new mutations will not get enough food, water etc. because the older, already full-grown generation would simply dominate their now-yet-full gorwn counterparts. So aging and death is nessesary for evolution, or the older generation would kill the new mutations and the older generation would get killed by the virus, predeator etc., which would kill the species. 
 
 I know, its not very uplifting but its true!
 But if your interested in the next few centuries we may be able to turn off the aging gene! So eat your greens and cross your fingers, cause if you life long enough you may be the first to under go the antiaging process (for real)! emoticon_xhoho to long life, and good genetics!
If you wanted to know why we have death in the god-created-the-universe sense I reall wouldn't know, all I know is the science sense.

 I am not actually trying to get anything other than to understand you a bit better (and others).
 
 You answered the question How death but not Why death. You say it is necessary to continue the species. I ask WHY is it necessary to continue the species. Species have died out certainly, ask you favorite dinosaur. Why does death exist at all. I am not looking for the "God answer". I'll gladly hear science and philosophy answers. If all came into being by accident then why does it ever end? Why should there be new mutations? What is wrong with continuing the old forever? What is the result of death? Do we just cease? 
 
 And more back on topic, do apes consider these things? Are they future oriented? Do they think about what will happen when grandpa dies?

Why is it neasescry to continue the species
 
 Any speices that does not want to live, won't live long. So when one animal came along that had a fear of death programed into its base mind, said animal was able to produce offspring more efficently then the other animal that didn't care about death, and didn't mind starving to death. The same goes for when one species has the urge to continue it self agiasnt on species that dosen't care either way. Obiously the species that did care would have a better chance then speices that didn't care. So here today are only the speices that did care about keeping the species alive, or their speices would be extinct. 
 
 
 
 Another reason death happens (genetic sense)-
 
 The first is the haymlick limit. This is the thing that cells are only programmed to copy themselves 50 times. This was built in because everytime a cell divides, a bit of the DNA strand gets lost at the tips of the strand, and if the cell kept dividing the DNA would lose more and more bits, until it made no sense at all. The haymlick limit prevents cells from falling apart because of rickity DNA strands (cancer is actually when our cells produce something to fill in the little bits of missing DNA, allowing them to break the haymlick limit and multiply out of control!). Now, a cell that can replicate itself 50 times and then has to stop may seem something unrelated to mortality, but it is not. If only 1,000,000 new bone cells are made, and each of those cells can only replicate itself 50 times, it may seem like more then enough cells, but in this senerio in the time it took for the 1,000,000 + bone cells to be produced, we, lets say lost 2,000,000. That is why we fade away when we grow old, the gap between number of new cells needed and number produced just gets larger and larger. 
 
 
 
 Why it is good to not live to be 600 years old-
 
 The second reason is it won't be much of a life. The average human loses
 about 25% of thier brain cells in a lifetime. Brain cells (or nerons) don't self-replicate and if you lived to be 600 years old you'd be to stupid to even think, let alone care about dieing.

Why is it neasescry to continue the species
 
 Any speices that does not want to live, won't live long. So when one animal came along that had a fear of death programed into its base mind, said animal was able to produce offspring more efficently then the other animal that didn't care about death, and didn't mind starving to death. The same goes for when one species has the urge to continue it self agiasnt on species that dosen't care either way. Obiously the species that did care would have a better chance then speices that didn't care. So here today are only the speices that did care about keeping the species alive, or their speices would be extinct.

The haymlick limit prevents cells from falling apart because of rickity DNA strands (cancer is actually when our cells produce something to fill in the little bits of missing DNA, allowing them to break the haymlick limit and multiply out of control!). Now, a cell that can replicate itself 50 times and then has to stop may seem something unrelated to mortality, but it is not. If only 1,000,000 new bone cells are made, and each of those cells can only replicate itself 50 times, it may seem like more then enough cells, but in this senerio in the time it took for the 1,000,000 + bone cells to be produced, we, lets say lost 2,000,000. That is why we fade away when we grow old, the gap between number of new cells needed and number produced just gets larger and larger. 
 
 
 
 Why it is good to not live to be 600 years old-
 
 The second reason is it won't be much of a life. The average human loses
 about 25% of thier brain cells in a lifetime. Brain cells (or nerons) don't self-replicate and if you lived to be 600 years old you'd be to stupid to even think, let alone care about dieing.

 
 The genetic limit argument makes sense. I definitely get the evolution argument but it makes no sense as one would have a difficult time showing that ants or cockroaches "want" to live. In fact, no one has ever demonstrated verifiable learning in an insect. Yet they are the most successful species on the planet. I am not going to buy the "caring about death is why death exists" argument. Simply doesn't fit with the data.
 
 However, you are not grasping the question. You say that the limit is built in. Why does there have to be a limit. Why could cells and neurons and brain cells etc go on forever. That would seem to indicate evolution. That brain cells were actually beginning to replicate. 
 
 You only show that the law of entropy is in full force in living systems. That things get worse over time not better. Natural selection does not negate the law of entropy but is supported by it. However, it makes no logical sense that natural selection had to develop that way. It could have developed the perfect species within a few permutations. In fact, statistically speaking we should all be living a thousand years by now, when in fact life spans have declined significantly since the beginning of recorded history.

New mutations have been programmed into our genes. When two people have a kid, that kid could have the same everything as his parents or he could be an einstien while his parents pick their noses on the porch. The reason their will always be new mutations is that things that don't mutate have been killed off by viruses and stuff, while things that mutate remained and nowadays are everywhere except in asexual reproduction. 
 
 If the old continued forever? Well first if the old went on forever the new would have no place to go. If people just got older we would fall apart literrally. 
 
 Death is the greatest unknown. 
 
 NO current generations of primite (excluding man) do not have sufficent congnitive ability to comprehend their own mortality and only fear death's causes (lion, tiger, starving etc.)
 
 Though on planet of the apes should the apes somehow reach that level of intellect they would proabably think about the future.
 
 All animals are a mix of worrying about the present and worrying about the future. Humans have the greatest portion leaning toward the future. Apes currently sometimes worrying about the future, but compared to humans who plan decades out, apes are realtivily quick-action animals. 
 
 Finally No, apes would steal grandpa's half-eaten maggot out of his mouth. Only humans see death as taboo because we know the enivitability of it happening to us. Animals see it like we see a guy with a flat tire begging for help on the side of the road (because they can't see like we can into the future).

Death is the greatest unknown. 
 
 

 
 Thank you.

 Interesting theory. However, there is still no demonstrable evidence that bugs learn. We learn. Primates and most mamals and fish and vertebrates in general learn. However, I don't think jelly fish or other invertabrates learn. 
 
 I spent a part of my college career trying to show that insects learned. I was working with flies. (Growing maggots for a living is hardly enjoyable). I was trying to use conditioned taste aversion. To do this (in rats) one introduces a novel flavor and then makes the animal sick. (Ever eat something new and get sick right after and then not be able to eat that ever again. I had that experience with Pepto Bismol. Puking pink is no fun.) To do this in flies one needs to make them hungry, how? You fly them. Put them on a record player tied to a string and they fly to exhaustion. You then give them water and sugar water choice. They take the sugar water rapidly. You then make them sick. This is where I got stuck. I couldn't find a way to make a fly sick that didn't kill them. I tried Nicotine in extremely miniscule amounts (approximately 1 part per trillion), I tried spinning them in a centrifuge at 2000 RPMs, and a few other things. It either killed them (the nicotine) or did nothing. 
 
 My point being that while animals know some things instinctually, (fight or flight) humans have overcome instinct. We can way lay the fight or flight response. This is the reason for military training. Chimps won't do this. Chimps, when confronted with an obvious agressor WILL backdown if they are losing and see it. Human's have trained that out of themselves. 
 
 This is why I asked for the death information. Humans will willingly sacrifice themselves, even needlessly. This is only seen in the protection of the young. True suicide is not seen in the animal kingdom. Whales, may beach themselves, but the cause is unknown. To say they want to die, is a huge stretch.
 
 Humans, have become more than self aware. We are others aware.

Interactions between the three basic drivings create many reactions. If someones urge to be socially accepted overran their urge for self-preservation that could lead to bolimia. Couple the three base motives with memory regonition to stimuli, the ability to long-term plan using subjective reasoning agiasnt defined base points and suffiecent cognitive ability to comprehend complex phenomina and you can explain most behavior in higher order animals.

 The awareness of others: You and I are both self aware. For a long time it has been suggested (about as long as evolution has been a theory) that is the pinacle of intelligence. We see this even in Start Trek episodes. Self awareness is important. However, Self Centeredness is what animals are about. They are about their own survival. Sacrifice for others is not really observed aside from a mother and her young. They have been observed to work together to preserve the herd, (or other appropriate name for the group) but it has never been observed that they will sacrifice for those they don't know. Our soldiers do. They don't know us and yet hundreds have sacrificed in Iraq for us. 
 
 Not meaning to throw the bible at you but The book of romans says that most won't die for a good man, although for a good man some might even die. However, Jesus died for us while we were his enemy. 
 
 This is other centeredness. You and I celebrate the birthdays of our friends. Apes do not. You and I recognize others as more important than ourselves. We can have humility as opposed to pride. Animals do not have that option. For them it is always get as high as possible for survival. You and I are distinctly different. 
 
 Thanks for sharing a bit about yourself.

I don't think it's genetic, at least not on the cognitive level. It has to go deeper, it has to lead somewhere outside of the genetic chain. I've said that man is the only creature with a sense of morality, so in essence, the question can be answered (in a very simplistic way) by that. We are a social animal, but then again, so are wolves. My belief is that man goes beyond just the physical and has another foot in the spiritual (meaning greater existence, not religion). The difference is, we ask why naturally. Apes ask why, but only when prompted. Such an example would be why the original poster thought of starting this thread.
When I was younger it was said that only man used tools. Now we know differently. Recently I have heard that we are the only ones to make tools that are used to make tools. Probably so.

Difference between humans/apes.
 
 We have American Idol?
 
 Seriously thought, not a lot. Someone said apes live off instinct and we don't...I'd have to disagree. I'd argue that all of us live most of our lives instinctually, and that you make fewer decisions based on abstract thinking than you do in instinctually motivated thinking. I'm here posting because I find it therapeutic to share and discuss..i.e. rewarding. I have a job because it feels good to have food/shelter/status. I eat and drink because I get "punished" if I don't, same goes for using the bathroom. I don't have a job in sales because I find sales to be uncomfortable...punishment, so I avoid it. However if there were enough reward it in, I might consider it. I.e. if the reward outweighed the punishment. So no, I don't find that most of my life decisions are based on some status of being "human, the most evolved of all earth's creatures." We're not so different. Many people fear that or are uncomfortable with the notion..but so what. Reason isn't here to be liked or loved or accepted. However, we, and most socials animals, conform to the need for a hierarchy, dominance, instinctually separating ourselves from those of a lower hierarchy, etc. Animals? Hah, we are humans..superior..yadyada. Seriously, think hard about every action/decisions you make or have made..what motivated it? Pleasure/pain. Don't feel bad though, it's how you got here! Plus you still have American Idol!! Seriously though, that doesn't make life any less special. Actually, nothing CAN be more special than your life so don't worry about it (by definition).
 
 Epaphras asked another good question: Are humans the pinnacle/end of the evolutionary chain? What's next?
 
 Not necessarily the pinnacle of evolution, however I think it's probable that one of three things will occur now that our civilization has become fairly secure and allows a lot of abstract thinking:
 
 1. Technology develops faster than our ability to responsibly use/control it resulting in a planet of the apes type scenario (end of civilization. but not the apes ruling thing...that's just possible, not probable.)
 2. We learn enough to know that we don't want to keep progressing and find some equilibrium and stay there (unlikely given our instincts).
 3. We either find a way to prolong life indefinitely, transfer consciousness, or (and/or) develop thinking machines/organisms that develop far beyond our capabilities and start a new era of life (through us or on their own), that is completely independent of the genetic evolution. Personally, I think we should all be working diligently towards #3 so we can make sure the other more likely #1 doesn't happen before we erase ourselves from existence. Besides, wouldn't it be interesting to free yourself from the randomness of the human condition? Sadly, not in our lifetime :) But place another stone for our children..one day we'll reach the top.
 
 I think the next biggest leap in evolutionary life will either be constructed by humans, or constructed by something that humans construct. That is of course if we don't count Sea Monkeys as the next step in evolution...I think they have nobility and thus a social system, at least they show a King Sea Monkey with a crown on the packaging...
 
 -mach

post_info.post_title: differences men/apes and the end of evolution

sorry, jumping in here 
 
 someone made a comment about insects not being able to learn
 
 bzz bzz honey bees!
 they scout out nectar, build a mental map (with their 800,000 brain cells) and remember where certain sources of nectar are, they then fly back and communicate to the other bees where the nectar sources are, or at least the general direction
 
 Menzel, R. (1990). Learning, memory and congnition in honey bees. In: Neurobiology of Comparative Cognition (Kesner, R.P. and Olten, D.S., eds.). Lawrence Erlbaum, Hillside, NJ, USA, pp. 237-292.
 
 Menzel, R. (1999). Memory dynamics in the honey bee. J. Comp. Physiol. 185: 323-340.
 
 Menzel, R. and Müller, U. (1996). Learning and memory in honey bees: from behavior to neural substrates. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 19: 379-404.
 
 Here is the abstract from the last paper:
 Learning and memory in honeybees is analyzed on five levels, using a topdown
 approach. (a) Observatory learning is applied during navigation and dance communication. (6) Local cues at the feeding site are learned associatively. (c) Classical conditioning of the proboscis extension response to olfactory stimuli provides insight into behavioral, neural, and neuropharmacological mechanisms of associative learning. (d) At the neural level, the pathways coding the conditioned and the unconditioned stimulus are identified. The reinforcing function of the unconditioned stimulus is traced to a particular neuron. (e) At the cellular level, the CAMP pathway is found to be critically involved. Nitric oxide is an essential mediator for the transfer from short- to long-term memory.
 
 Anyway, this topic is not philosphy. Maybe it was 200 years ago, but now it's science.

I agree with Draconis in that humans simply operate on a higher level of instinctual behavior. That fact that we don't live in a dog eat dog society is because all humans prefer to live. It was more beneficial to the human race if humans lived together in packs, much as lions do. It is a sort of "I'll scratch your back, you can scratch mine" kinda thing. However, a human is no lion. Humans are by far one of the more physically weaker species on the planet. For this reason, the larger the pack of humans, the greater the chances of survival.
 
 Now, for this pack to survive, a few things are needed. First, what can members of the pack do to each other? This is where the issue of morals can be brought up. Each pack of humans needs to decide what is acceptable and what is not. The actions that are acceptable are those that are not harmful to the well being of the pack. This is how "morals" came into being. Society defines an act to be moral if it benefits society as a whole. Murder, for instance, is considered an immoral act. Murder weakens the chance for the entire pack to survive. And why must the entire pack survive? Because humans cannot live on their own. 
 
 
Relient Halo: My belief is that man goes beyond just the physical and has another foot in the spiritual (meaning greater existence, not religion). The difference is, we ask why naturally. Apes ask why, but only when prompted. Such an example would be why the original poster thought of starting this thread.

 
 First off, the reason man developed a sense of greater existance relates back to the instictual behavior of survival. But what, you may ask, does religion have to do with behavior? Well, humans had figured out, for the most part, to survive in the real world. But, for some reason, humans died anyways. No matter what they did, no matter how healthy, the human would die regardless. This wasn't looking all that great in the eyes of the "survival-a-mentalist". Therefore, the logical path was to insure a type of survival after death. Thus the spiritual. It is much easier to say, "when i die, i will still live spiritually" than to say, "no matter what i do, i will die". Therefore religion.
 
 Ok, time to backtrack to what else a pack of humans need to survive. In order for the unit to work as a whole, the humans need a common goal, and a common plan to achieve the goal. Let's say a human sees a baffalo. Human wants buffalo. However, so does the pack. Instead of fighting, an agreement is reached to share the baffalo to ensure complete survival. Therefore, a plan must be devised as to how to kill and share the buffalo. Many humans have, through trial and error, deduced (as do monkeys and dogs and other animals) that the best way to kill a baffalo is to, let us pretend, sneak up on it and jump it. However, to jump a baffalo, all the humans must jump it at once. Therefore a leader must be chosen. This is the second need of humans. A leader. Because of the basic animalistic instinct of survival, humans have developed close in-pack relationships, well defined morals as to how to behave within the society, and leadership.
 
 Ok, im done with that, but there is something else i would like to address. Many people say that we possess higher cognative skills, and that is what defines a human from an ape. But, cognitive skills are simply the result of a need for survival. All inventions are created to make life easier, to make survival easier. Just as we use tools to lessen our work, monkeys (or chimps, i can never remember which one) use tools to lessen their work. Its just that we are a lot damn lazier, so we need better tools.
 
 You see, no matter what you may think humans have that animals don't, the "special human characteristic" is simply and organized, long-term (i think someone else used this word) approach to living. Humans recognize the increase in survival if they worked together. Morals, religion, "higher cognative skills", these are just complex paths to ensure survival.
 
 I also place a challenge as that no one here can describe a human characteristic that cannot be linked back to basic instinctual survival.

Wow, finally someone came to the philosophy section. I posted this on the creation vs. evolution thread as well just to get a bite.
 
 I will ask a similar question, How is religion instinctual? Are we the culmination of evolution, if not, what is the next level? Is the planet of the apes possible?

 
 I think that everyone is missing the point here. First of all, technically what seperates humans from every other species (apes, birds, dogs, etc.) is our ability to understand abstract concepts, i.e. death. This can be attributed to our large cerebral cortex in our brain, which is where all of our higher information processing occurs. This is why we humans can understand calculus; whereas apes will never be able to comprehend this concept. Furthermore, animals cannot fully comprehend death. For example, a deer that runs into the middle of the road because it is attracted to a car's headlights can comprehend the pain and can actually fear being hurt, but it cannot comprehend the end that is death. This is not true for humans, and is one of our distinguishing features. Thus, can religion essentialy be attributed to human instinct? By this I mean can religion be considered a human instinct that is wired in our brain to compensate for this end we have no tangible answer for? Furthermore, if it is in fact instinctual, is it instinctual for a reason? Did God, or some higher being program us with this instinct to seperate us from animals, and in turn give us the ability to act upon this instinct or to deny it all together? Is this the reason why we have a soul, or why we can go to Heaven (based upon one's own beliefs), or is this just an instict which human's have created in order to make sense of a perceived end which has no tangible answer? Any feedback or thoughts would be great, because I'm currently researching this topic.

post_info.post_title: why in fact religion may be instinctual

To dismiss all thoughts that we as humans are not disticnt from apes:
 
 First off if we were meant to be on the level of apes we would not be able to develop civilizations, societies. Can you imagine apes with their own civilization, using currency, checking their email? It simply can not be the case for if it were meant to be that would be the case. Apes are not on the same level as humans and weren't meant to be.

This is not intended to be a creation evolution debate and I hope folks will refrain from that.
 
 I believe that there are characteristics which are solely attributable to humans. Before I post my thoughts I would like to hear others. I don't wish to influence any answers. 
 
 So what do you all think. By the Way, "nothing" is also a reasonable response, but it will be hard to prove.

 --------------------------------------------------------------------------
 (Time.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
 (Time.)

 
 If so, why do we still have apes, and why are there no transitional species that we can currently observe. Statistical averages say we should see a few hundred within the last two centuries, at a minimum.

If so, why do we still have apes, and why are there no transitional species that we can currently observe. Statistical averages say we should see a few hundred within the last two centuries, at a minimum.

 --------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
 How are we to know that there has not been a few hundred,there are none in my neighborhood,how aboput yours???

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
 How are we to know that there has not been a few hundred,there are none in my neighborhood,how aboput yours???

 
 There are precious few areas on the planet that have not been explored. Those that haven't would not support the kinds of life we are talking about. There is no evidence of any interim species of apes and humans. Not one shred. Those items in the fossil record that are claimed as possibles are only possibles, are dubious at best, and are extremely rare. A recent study also showed that most characteristics of supposed alternate species of hominids were well within the variation seen in current homo sapiens. 
 
 The point I was making is that if they existed we would see them.

 First off if we were meant to be on the level of apes we would not be able to develop civilizations, societies. Can you imagine apes with their own civilization, using currency, checking their email? It simply can not be the case for if it were meant to be that would be the case. Apes are not on the same level as humans and weren't meant to be.

 
 Look back a couple thousand years ago and you could say the same about humans. When we humans were just in caves. Discoveries came over time. When we discovered electricity we didn't immediately invent the computer and email, it took some time. Mainly there is one other thing that separates us. We have opposable thumbs. We can hold things in our hands and that is mainly what separates us. It's not our brains, but our hands, and lots and lots of time.
